title-group.article-title: Hybrid synchronization phenomenon in two coupled delay hyperchaotic Lorenz systems with unknown parameters via a single linear controller

article-meta.aff: School of Mathematical Sciences, Yancheng Teachers University, China

author-notes.corresp: Zuolei Wang, School of Mathematical Sciences, Yancheng Teachers University, Yancheng, 224002, China Email: wangzuolei1971@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This work is devoted to investigating the hybrid synchronization phenomenon of two identical hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems with different initial conditions, and a simple coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization scheme only with a single variable controller is proposed. Based on the Lyapunov stability theory, sufficient conditions of synchronization are obtained for both linear feedback and adaptive control approaches. The problem of adaptive synchronization between two nearly identical chaotic systems with unknown parameters is also studied. A single input adaptive synchronization controller is proposed and the adaptive parameter update laws are developed. Numerical simulation results are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed chaos synchronization scheme.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: During the last decade, synchronization of chaotic systems, an important topic in nonlinear science, has attracted increasing attention and has been explored intensively. Since Pecora and Carrol (1996) introduced a method to synchronize two identical systems with different initial conditions, a variety of approaches, which include complete synchronization (Wang et al., 2005; Luo, 2009), phase synchronization (Ge and Chen, 2004; Fujisaka et al., 2005), generalized synchronization (Yang and Hu, 2007), lag synchronization (Shahverdiev et al., 2002; Li et al., 2005; Wang et al., 2011), Q-S synchronization (Hu and Xu, 2008), anti-synchronization (Chiang et al., 2008; Al-Sawalha and Noorani, 2009; Al-Sawalha et al., 2010), time-scale synchronization (Ma et al., 2008, 2011; Wang and Shi, 2009). Functional synchronization (Banerjee and Chowdhury, 2009), projective synchronization (Li and Xu, 2004; Hu et al., 2007; Feng et al., 2008), cluster synchronization (Qin and Chen, 2004) and so on, have been proposed and successfully applied to the chaos synchronization of chaotic or hyperchaotic systems.

Many theoretical studies of chaos synchronization have been carried out for unidirectionally coupled identical systems, usually via the feedback approach (Park, 2006; Wang, 2010). In this case, linear feedback via a single variable may be a better choice because of its simplicity for the theoretical analysis and circuit implementation. In most cases of drive-response synchronization, all the states of the response system synchronize to the corresponding states of drive system in terms of the same synchronization regime. As we all know, complete synchronization is characterized by the equality of state variables while evolving in time. Anti-synchronization is characterized by the disappearance of the sum of relevant variables (Ma et al., 2011). Does the phenomenon that some states part of the interactive systems are synchronized in terms of one type of synchronization regime, and other states are synchronized in terms of another type exist in unidirectionally and linearly coupled chaotic systems? There is no doubt that it is an interesting problem. Therefore, inspired by Li et al. (2008), Chen et al. (2009), and Zhang et al. (2010),the hybrid synchronization of time-delay chaotic systems is investigated by using single control input both for theoretical research and practical applications. However, as far as we know, there have been few (if any) results in the literature on an investigation for the delay chaotic systems via a single controller with one variable, especially time-delay hyperchaotic systems.

In this paper, we will show that the coexistence phenomenon of synchronizations between two identical hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems can be achieved only by a single variable controller. Based on the Lyapunov stability theory, a simple synchronization scheme is proposed, and sufficient conditions for achieving synchronization are derived. Numerical simulation results are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed synchronization scheme.

sec.title: 2. Dynamical behavior of hyperchaotic Lorenz system with time delay
sec.p:
In this paper, the considered hyperchaotic Lorenz system with time delay is described as (1)x·=a(y-x)+rw(t-τ),y·=cx-y-xz,z·=xy-bz,w·=-yz-dw, where τ>0 is the time delay. When τ=0, system (1) is the hyperchaotic system constructed by Wang and Wang (2007). It is well known that time delay is ubiquitous in most natural systems, such as physical, chemical, biological system. As the dynamical systems given by delay differential equations (DDEs) have an infinite dimensional state space, usually the attractors of the solutions are high dimensional. By the Galerkin approximation technique, an algorithm considered by Ghosh et al. (2008) or calculating Lyapunov exponents for a system with time delay, when a = 10, b = 8/3, c = 28, d = 1, r = 1 and the time delay τ is chosen as 1, system (1) has two positive Lyapunov exponents, i.e., λ1 = 0.6513, λ2 = 0.1394, and the hyperchaotic attractors of system (1) are shown in Figure 1 (3D overview). Figure 1.
3D overview hyperchaotic attractor of equation (1) with a = 10, b = 8/3, c = 28, d = 1, r = 1, τ = 1, (a) (x,y,z), (b) (x,y,w), (c) (y, z, w).

sec.title: 3. Hybrid synchronization regime of hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems via a single linear control
sec.p: Because it possesses at least two positive Lyapunov exponents and has more complex behavior than a hyperchaotic system, the hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay system is more suitable for some special engineering applications such as secure communication. In the following sections, we will investigate the synchronization of two identical hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems via a single feedback control only with one variable. For convenience, the drive hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay system is given in the following form: (2)x·1=a(y1-x1)+rw1(t-τ),y·1=cx1-y1-x1z1,z·1=x1y1-bz1,w·1=-y1z1-dw1, and the response hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay system is written as (3)x·2=a(y2-x2)+rw2(t-τ)+u1,y·2=cx2-y2-x2z2+u2,z·2=x2y2-bz2+u3,w·2=-y2z2-dw2+u4, where u1, u2, u3, u4 are controllers to be constructed, and the number of controllers are uncertain.

The aim of this paper is to find a single controller, such that when the controller is chosen, the states variable x2, y2 and w2 in the response system are anti-phase synchronized, respectively, to the x1, y1 and w1 in drive system, simultaneously the third state variable z2 is complete-synchronized to z1. For this purpose, let (4)e1=x2+x1,e2=y2+y1,e3=z2-z1,e4=w2+w1,

It follows from equations (2) and (3) that the error (4) is governed by the following dynamical system: (5)e·1=a(e2-e1)+re4(t-τ)+u1,e·2=ce1-e2-z1e1-x2e3+u2,e·3=x2e2-y1e1-be3+u3,e·4=y1e3-z2e2-de4+u4, where ui = -kiei and ki (i=1,2,3,4) is the positive feedback gains.

In a practical way, a smaller number of controllers and a simpler form of controllers are greatly practical. The control goal is to propose a single input controller such that the state errors in equation (5) satisfy (6)limt→∞e1(t)=0,limt→∞e2(t)=0,limt→∞e3(t)=0,limt→∞e4(t)=0.
With this in mind, the proposed schemes are described below.

sec.title: 3.1. Hybrid synchronization of hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems via a single linear control

statement.title: Theorem 1.
statement.p: For the given drive system (2), the response system (3) with controllers to be designed and the corresponding error dynamical system (5), suppose that H is the upper bound of the absolute value of state variables of the drive system and the response system, if the following kind of linear control law is applied to system (3): (7)u1=-k1e1,ui=0(i=2,3,4), where the positive gain k1 is satisfied k1>max{a11,a122+a11, a122+H2/4b+a11, [H4/16-[2a12+(d-α-a122)]H2/4-a122b(d-α)] /[(1+b)H2/4-b(d-α)]+a11}, where a11 = 12rλ-1-a, a12 = -12(a+c+H) and λ is a suitable positive real number,

Then, the zero solution of the error dynamical system (5) is globally asymptotically stable, and thus the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of system (2) and (3) can be obtained, namely, the state variables x2, y2 and w2 in the response system are anti-phase synchronized to x1, y1 and w1 in the drive system, simultaneously, the third state variable z2 is complete-synchronized to z1, respectively.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The positive definite Lyapunov function is chosen as (8)V=12[e12+e22+e32+e42]+α∫t-τte42dt, where α>0.

sec.p: Calculating the time derivative of the Lyapunov function (8) along the trajectory of system (5) arrives at (9)V·=e1e·1+e2e·2+e3e·3+e4e·4+αe42-αe42(t-τ) =e1[a(e2-e1)+re4(t-τ)]-k1e12 +e2[ce1-e2-z1e1-x2e3]+e3[x2e2-y1e1-be3] +e4[y1e3-z2e2-de4]+αe42-αe42(t-τ) =-(a+k1)e12-e22-be32-(d-α)e42 +(a+c-z1)e1e2-y1e1e3-z2e2e4+y1e3e4 +re1e4(t-τ)-αe42(t-τ).

Since a chaotic system has bounded trajectories, there exists a positive constant H, such that |xi|, |yi|, |zi| and |wi|≤H(i=1,2), for a suitable positive real number λ, (10)V·≤-(a+k1-12rλ-1)e12-e22-be32-(d-α)e42 +(a+c+H)|e1||e2|+H|e1||e3|+H|e2||e4| +H|e3||e4|+(12rλ-α)e42(t-τ) =-(|e1|,|e2|,|e3|,|e4|)Q(|e1|,|e2|,|e3|,|e4|)T -(α-12λr)e42(t-τ), where (11)Q=(k1-a11a12-H/20a1210-H/2-H/20b-H/20-H/2-H/2d-α).

It is obvious that, for suitable values of λ, α, when α-12λr>0 and k1>max{a11,a122+a11,a122+H2/4b+a11, [H4/16-[2a12+(d-α-a122)]H2 /4-a122b(d-α)]/[(1+b)H2/4-b(d-α)]+a11}, the real symmetrical matrix Q will be positive definite, and V· is negative semi-definite. So one obtains e→0 and eτ→0 as t→∞, namely, limt→∞ |e |=0. It follows that the zero solution of the error dynamical system (5) is globally asymptotically stable, and thus the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of systems (2) and (3) can be obtained, namely, the states variable x2, y2 and w2 in the response system are anti-phase synchronized to x1, y1 and w1 in the drive system, simultaneously, the third state variable z2 is complete-synchronized to z1, respectively. This completes the proof.

sec.title: 3.2. Hybrid synchronization of hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems via a single adaptive linear control
sec.p:
The linear feedback control laws proposed in Theorem 1 have a fixed feedback gain no matter how many initial error values there are at first. Thus, it may be a waste to spend time on searching the feedback gain in practice. In this section, the adaptive control technology is applied to accomplish the synchronization of two identical hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems. Theorem 2.
For the given drive system (2), the response system (3), and the corresponding error dynamical system (5), if the following adaptive control law is applied to system (3): (12)u1=-k1e1,ui=0(i=2,3,4), where k1 is an estimated feedback gain updated according to the following adaptation algorithm (13)k·1=e12, Then, the zero solution of the error dynamical system (5) is globally asymptotically stable, and the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization between the system (2) and system (3) can be observed.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The positive definite Lyapunov function is chosen as (14)V=12[e12+e22+e32+e42+(k1-l1)2]+α∫t-τte42dt, where α,l1>0.

sec.p: Calculating the time derivative of the Lyapunov function (14) along the trajectory of system (5) arrives at (15)V·=e1e·1+e2e·2+e3e·3+e4e·4+(k1-l1)k·1 +αe42-αe42(t-τ)=e1[a(e2-e1)+re4(t-τ)] -k1e12+e2[ce1-e2-z1e1-x2e3] +e3[x2e2-y1e1-be3]+e4[y1e3-z2e2-de4] +(k1-l1)e12+αe42-αe42(t-τ) =-(a+l1)e12-e22-be32-(d-α)e42 +(a+c-z1)e1e2-y1e1e3-z2e2e4+y1e3e4 +re1e4(t-τ)-αe42(t-τ).

Because equation (15) is the same as equation (9), it is obvious that, for suitable values of λ, α and sufficient large values of l1, V· will be negative semi-definite. So one obtains e→0 and eτ→0 as t→∞, namely, limt→∞ |e |=0. It follows that the zero solution of the error dynamical system (5) is globally asymptotically stable, and thus the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of systems (2) and (3) with the controller (12) associated with (13) can be obtained, namely, the states variables x2, y2 and w2 in the response system are anti-phase synchronized to x1, y1 and w1 in the drive system, simultaneously, the third state variable z2 is complete-synchronized to z1, respectively. This completes the proof.

sec.title: 3.3. Hybrid synchronization of hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems with unknown parameters via a single adaptive linear control
sec.p: In practical applications, some or all of the system parameters cannot be exactly known in advance. Therefore, it is essential to study the synchronization problem of chaotic systems in the presence of unknown system parameters. In the following text, the aforementioned adaptive control law is used to synchronize two nearly identical hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems with unknown parameters of the response system in spite of the difference in initial conditions.

For this case, the drive system is designed as (2) and the response system is modeled as follows: (16)x·2=a1(t)(y2-x2)+r1(t)w2(t-τ)+u1,y·2=c1(t)x2-y2-x2z2+u2,z·2=x2y2-b1(t)z2+u3,w·2=-y2z2-d1(t)w2+u4, where u1, u2, u3, u4 are controllers to be constructed. The system parameters a, b, c, d, r in the drive system (2) are known, but a1(t), b1(t), c1(t), d1(t), r1(t) in the response system (16) are unknown parameters which need to be estimated. Theorem 3.
Systems (2) and (16) will approach hybrid synchronization for any initial condition, if the controllers are taken as (17)u1=-k1e1,ui=0(i=2,3,4), and the adaptive laws of parameters are taken as (18)k·1=e12,a·1(t)=(x2-y2)e1,b·1(t)=z2e3,c·1(t)=-x2e2,d·1(t)=y2e2,r·1(t)=w2(t-τ)e1.
Proof.
The following error dynamical system can be abtained from drive system (2) and response system (16) (19)e·1=a(e2-e1)+re4(t-τ)+(r1(t)-r)w2(t-τ) +(a1(t)-a)(y2-x2)+u1,e·2=ce1-e2-z1e1-x2e3+(c1(t)-c)x2,e·3=x2e2-y1e1-be3-(b1(t)-b)z2,e·4=y1e3-z2e2-de4-(d1(t)-d)w2.
Construct a positive definite Lyapunov function as following (20)V=12[e12+e22+e32+e42+(k1-l1)2 +(a1(t)-a)2+(b1(t)-b)2+(c1(t)-c)2 +(d1(t)-d)2+(r1(t)-r)2]+α∫t-τte42dt, where α>0 and l1 > 0.

Calculating the time derivative of the Lyapunov function (20) along the trajectory of system (19) associated with control law and estimated parameters law, we have (21)V·=e1e·1+e2e·2+e3e·3+e4e·4+(k1-l1)k·1 +αe42-αe42(t-τ)+(a1(t)-a)a·1(t) +(b1(t)-b)b·1(t)+(c1(t)-c)c·1(t)+(d1(t)-d1)d·1(t) =e1[a(e2-e1)+re4(t-τ)+(r1(t)-r)w2(t-τ) +(a1(t)-a)(y2-x2)-k1e1] +e2[ce1-e2-z1e1-x2e3+(c1(t)-c)x2] +e3[x2e2-y1e1-be3-(b1(t)-b)z2] +e4[y1e3-z2e2-de4-(d1(t)-d)w2] +(k1-l1)e12+αe42-αe42(t-τ) -(a1(t)-a)(y2-x2)e1 +(b1(t)-b)z2e3-(c1(t)-c)x2e2+(d1(t)-d1)w2e4 -(r1(t)-r1)w2(t-τ)e1=-(a+l1)e12-e22-be32 -(d-α)e42+(a+c-z1)e1e2-y1e1e3-z2e2e4 +y1e3e4+e1e4(t-τ)-αe42(t-τ).

It is obvious that equation (21) is the same as equation (9), with suitable values of λ, α and sufficient large values of l1, V· will be negative semi-definite and the zero solution of the error dynamical system (19) can be globally asymptotically stable. So the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of systems (2) and (16) with the controller (17) associated with (18) can be obtained, namely, the state variables x2, y2 and w2 in the response system are anti-phase synchronized to x1, y1and w1 in the drive system, simultaneously, the third state variable z2 is complete-synchronized to z1, respectively. This completes the proof.

sec.title: 4. Illustrative numerical simulation examples
sec.p: In this section, some numerical examples are presented to illustrate the theoretical analysis. The system parameters are selected as a = 10, b = 8/3, c = 28, d = 1, r = 1 and the value of time delay τ is assumed as 1.0. The initial values of the drive system and the response system are chosen as (x1(0), y1(0), z1(0), w1(0)) = (0.82, 0.29, 0.48, 0.1) and (x2(0), y2(0), z2(0), w2(0)) = (0.78, 0.3, 0.25, 0.3), respectively. The two uncoupled time-delay systems will be of different hyperchaotic behaviors with the above parameter values and the initial values. Furthermore, the initial values of the unknown parameters in the response system are chosen as random.

When the controllers are taken as in Theorem 1, time evolution curves of two systems with the controllers in equation (7) (where k1 = 6.0) and the synchronization errors are shown in Figure 2 and Figure 3, respectively. From Figures 2 and 3, it is obvious that the synchronization errors converge asymptotically to zero. From the numerical simulation results, the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of systems (2) and (3) can be obtained under the condition of Theorem 1. From the theoretical analysis, it is known that conditions for the synchronization obtained analytically are only the sufficient conditions. But in a practical way, k1 can be obtained by numerical methods. In order to explore the synchronization behavior of the scheme, k1 is taken as bifurcation parameter to see how the solution of e2 evolves with the variation of the parameter. From the bifurcation diagram plotted in Figure 4, it can be observed that e2 converges to zero at about k1 = 5.5685, which means that the synchronization can be achieved when k1 > 5.5685. Figure 2.
Time evolution curves of two systems with the controllers in (7), where k1 = 6.0. (a) (x1,x2), (b) (y1,y2), (c) (z1,z2), (d) (w1,w2).
Figure 3.
Dynamics of synchronization error states e1, e2, e3 and e4 with the controllers in (7), where k1 = 6.0. (a) e1, (b) e2, (c) e3, (d) e4.
Figure 4.
Bifurcation diagram of e2 versus the parameter k1.

When the controllers are chosen as in Theorem 2, the synchronization errors between the drive system and the response system are shown in Figure 5. The estimation of feedback gain is shown in Figure 6. From the numerical simulation results, it is obvious that the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of the two identical hyperchaotic Lorenz time-delay systems with different initial conditions are indeed achieved. Figure 5.
Dynamics of synchronization error states e1, e2, e3 and e4 with the controllers in (12). (a) e1, (b) e2, (c) e3, (d) e4.
Figure 6.
The estimation of feedback gain k1.

When the controllers are chosen as in Theorem 3, the synchronization errors of the systems (2) and (16) are shown in Figure 7. The estimations of the parameters are shown in Figure 8. From these figures, it is obvious that the synchronization errors converge asymptotically to zero and two systems with mismatched parameters are indeed achieved with hybrid synchronization. Figure 7.
Dynamics of synchronization error states e1, e2, e3 and e4 with the controller in (17). (a) e1, (b) e2, (c) e3, (d) e4.
Figure 8.
The estimations of the unknown parameters in the response system (16). (a) a1(t), (b) b1(t), (c) c1(t), (d) d1(t), (e) r1(t).

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, a class of hybrid synchronization phenomenon of the two identical hyperchaotic time-delay systems via a single linear variable control is investigated. The coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization of two identical hyperchaotic Lorenz systems are realized even with unknown parameters. Sufficient conditions for the hybrid synchronization are obtained in terms of asymptotical stability. The controller is based on feedback control which needs only a linear feedback controller, thus, the coexistence of anti-phase and complete synchronization can be realized by the physical configuration of the electronic set up, which is of important significance in using chaos synchronization for applications. Furthermore, numerical simulations are provided to show the effectiveness of the developed methods.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 11102180 and No. 51178157) and the Natural Science Foundation of the Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions of China (Grant No. 10KJB120005).
